metadata.case_name: Bidi Manufacturing Company and Director v. State of Maharashtra

facts.text: The first petitioner is a private limited Company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1913 and the second petitioner is a Director of the Company.
The Company maintains 23 establishments for manufacturing bidis in the District of Nasik, Poona and Ahmednagar in the State of Maharashtra.
A large majority of these establishments are borne on the register of factories maintained by the Chief Inspector of Factories under the Factories Act, 1948.

Craftsmen called rollers attend these establishments and prepare bidis using materials supplied by the Company. Establishments remain open during specified hours but rollers are not bound to attend for any fixed period; a roller may come to and leave the establishment as convenient to him, and is paid for bidis turned out according to a fixed tariff.
This is the accepted modus operandi of work in bidi establishments in the Maharashtra region.

Bombay High Court in State v. Alisaheb Kashim Tamboli held these establishments are factories and rollers are workers under Factories Act, 1948; expression 'employed' in s.2(1) does not necessarily involve master-servant relationship.

Supreme Court in Shankar Balaji Waje v. State of Maharashtra held bidi rollers not 'employed' under s.2(1) due to no contract of service, no fixed hours, free to come/go/leave, no supervision, paid per quantity, etc.; thus not entitled to ss.79 and 80 benefits.
Post-Shankar Balaji judgment, owners of bidi establishments in Maharashtra denied weekly holidays, wages in lieu, and access to Factories Act Inspectors.
More than 35,000 bidi rollers in Maharashtra on payrolls of registered bidi establishments; many other unregistered; grave unrest among rollers due to denial of prior benefits.

Government of Maharashtra issued Notification under s.85 of Factories Act declaring all provisions apply to specified places (including many of Company's establishments) notwithstanding persons not employed by owner but working with permission or agreement; provided not by owner with family only.
Effect of Notification: places deemed factories, owners deemed occupiers, persons working therein deemed workers entitled to Act benefits.
Petitioners challenged validity of s.85 and Notification under Arts.14 and 19(1)(g).

Historical factory legislation: Acts of 1881,1891,1911; Royal Commission 1931 highlighted poor bidi conditions (overcrowding, insanitary, long hours, no holidays); recommended extension to small power-less places.
Labour Investigation Committee 1944 confirmed poor bidi conditions especially in Bombay.

Affidavit of V.N. Pimenta (Under Secretary, Maharashtra): Notification to protect rollers post-Shankar Balaji, maintain prior benefits; selected registered factories first; enquiring others for inclusion.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.85 of Factories Act and Notification thereunder infringe fundamental rights under Arts.14 and 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.
Whether s.85 imposes unreasonable restrictions on right to carry on business and enables arbitrary discrimination.
Whether application of all provisions including ss.79 and 80 to deemed workers is unreasonable.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.85 and Notification impose unreasonable restrictions upon fundamental right to carry on business under Art.19(1)(g).
S.85 confers unguided power on State to arbitrarily discriminate between similarly situated owners by selecting places via Notification.
Provisions like ss.79 and 80 inapplicable to rollers without fixed attendance, imposing unreasonable restrictions.

respondent_arguments.text: Notification issued to protect bidi rollers against exploitation and deprivation of prior benefits post-Shankar Balaji; selected registered factories first for industrial peace.
Enquiries ongoing for other establishments; rational basis for initial selection.

court_reasoning.text: Factory legislation history shows need to protect bidi workers from poor conditions; s.85 extends benefits to needed cases without being unreasonable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restrictions serve health/safety; not unreasonable under Art.19(1)(g).

court_reasoning.text: S.85 guided by policy to protect workers in hazardous employments based on local conditions; not arbitrary discrimination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Selective application permissible if rational; akin to Minimum Wages Act.

court_reasoning.text: Notification's selection of registered factories rational in emergency post-SC judgment unrest.
Ss.79/80 apply to deemed workers only if they work full factory hours for 240+ days; no unreasonableness.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conditions must be fulfilled; consistent with Bridhichand.

holdings.text: S.85 valid; does not infringe Art.19(1)(g) as restrictions reasonable for worker protection.
S.85 and Notification not discriminatory under Art.14; guided by intelligible differentia.
Ss.79/80 applicable to deemed workers fulfilling full attendance/240 days condition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shankar Balaji Waje v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Held bidi rollers not workers; prompted notification but does not preclude s.85 deeming.
HC held rollers workers; overruled by SC but prior benefits relied on.

precedents_cited.case_name: M.S. Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya v. Sangamner Akola Taluka Bidi Kamgar Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Selective application under delegated power valid if policy-guided; applies to s.85.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bridhichand Sharma v. First Civil Judge, Nagpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Bidi rollers entitled to s.79 if fulfill days/attendance; applies analogously.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Chandra Prasad v. State of Bihar

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Definitions of factory/worker; power to deem applicability; annual leave provisions extended reasonably.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality; right to trade; writ for fundamental rights enforcement.

outcome.summary: The Court upheld the validity of s.85 of the Factories Act, 1948 and the Maharashtra Government's Notification thereunder, finding no infringement of Arts.14 or 19(1)(g); petition challenging them dismissed.

key_quotes.text: The section is enacted with the object of conferring authority to extend in appropriate cases the provisions of the Act to establishments which are otherwise not factories within the meaning of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Provisions made for the benefit of deemed workers cannot therefore be regarded as unreasonable within the meaning of Art.19(1)(g) of the Constitution.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Selective application of a law according to the exigencies where it is sanctioned, ordinarily results in permissible classification.
key_quotes.speaker: court
